data.text: ">Shelly Stark And I only carry the basics. Been touring 40 years, 9 months a year. Never learned to drive any motor vehicles. But bicycled all over the country. Started age 26, I'm 66 now. In October I'll start my 41st year.
data.author: Gary Palmer

data.text: fantastic! Cool rig. I‚Äôm 64 and just starting out!
data.author: Shelly Stark

data.text: I used to work 3 months a year from 1980 to 2018 when I retired. Took September to May off. Now retired 4 years and travel October to May. It's been a great life. Hitchhiked 5 years and 50k before I started bike touring. Biked about 300,000 miles. It's a great way to travel, nice and slow.
data.author: Gary Palmer

data.text: 1. NiteRider Lumina Light- I ride in the dark. A lot. 2. Various helmets- For head protection and a place to mount the NiteRider light. 3. Panniers- Allows me to carry everything I need: Groceries, change of clothes, etc. 4. Multitool- A Leatherman when I'm commuting or a Topeak multitool if I'm touring. 5. Kenda KwickTrax commuter tires with kevlar lining.

data.author: Philip Lenaghan

data.text: On my first bike trip I was crazy about buying all the stuff I 'need', halfway into the trip I met and cycled with a German girl for a week, she had a cheap cheap bike, cheap bags, nothing fancy and it all worked completely fine. It depends on what kind of touring you're doing but you really don't need much

data.text: Panniers, Burley coho trailer, MSR stove, solo stove and loppers. Yes it seems excessive, but it helps evening the weight and I have two ways to cook depends on the weather. Raining/ snowing? Cook in my tent. Nice out cooking with wood also as long as you don't over fill it with wood it's minimal visibility to others. I also have a gosun sport for when it's sunny outside and too hot to have a üî• going of any sort. ‚ù§. I'm gonna say storage and eating are key to my setup üòâ
